characters: INT. INTENSIVE CARE. HOSPITAL. HOUSTON, TX- DAY
-- GRABS ERIN BY THE HAIR, TRYING TO PULL HER FROM THE CA
THE ELEMENTAL INFERNO OF A SHUTTLE BOOSTER AT LIFT OFF --
RUTH DRESSED AS AN ASTRONAUT. THE PICTURE OF LAURA AS A
FOR A FEW MOMENTS WITH HER HALF IN AND HALF OUT OF THE CA
DREW TOUCHING HER HAND. SEEDS SPLIT AND GROW. RAIN SPLASH
SCREAMING INTO HER HELMET AS SHE EXITS THE ATMOSPHERE.
MARK AND PETE AND JIM IN UNISON
SUDDENLY LAURA SEEMS COMPLETLEY AWARE OF HER BEHAVIOUR
A FUCKING GUN IN OUR CAR
FOR CHRISTS SAKE LAURA WHY IS THERE
INT. CONTROL ROOM. NEUTRAL BOUYANCY LAB. DAY
LAURA REACHES THROUGH THE WINDOW AND OPENS THE DOOR --
LITTLE GIRL NEXT TO HER NANA. LAURA ON A BEACH LAUGHING.
-- A FLASHING RED LIGHT FILLS THE CABIN --

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Not bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What? Beat. Is she serious?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Wallace, you just spent seven hours in space, surrounded by God's celestial beauty. Tell me you looked around.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Next time.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CREW QUARTERS. INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION - “NIGHT” Laura and the crew sleep strapped into insulation bags attached to the shuttle walls. In micro G, the unconsciou astronauts seem frozen -- arms bent, hair stood out on en We FIND LAURA, at peace, dreaming zero G dreams. We HEAR MAN's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s right, honey. Mommy’s up in space right now. We hear a little boy's voice.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, she’s -- you remember mommy showed you -- how there’s a building in space -- a station -- and the people in it, they need food and water. And somebody to fix the fridge when it breaks. So we send astronauts to fly up there and do a job.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And mommy’s an astronaut.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Her eyelids moving as she dreams.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That’s right. It’s all she ever wanted to be, and she did it. Yay, mommy! A long beat and then we hear a LOW TONE and the song HERE COMES THE SUN by the BEATLES fills the cabin. The lights up gently. The crew stirs, moving slowly. All except Laur who's EYES SNAP OPEN at the tone. She springs into action

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. INTERNATIONAL SPACE STATION - “NIGHT” The CREW eats, dressed in branded fleece, getting used to zero gravity.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: So today is EVA two. We’1l be offloading the MPLM. Chithra and Henckle are on the arm. I’m on point with Wallace and Cole.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She eats efficiently, rolling each tube from the bottom, folding her foil packets.  Bo A German Astronaut, MILES HENCKLE (30s) is sitting next t her. He is looking at a PHOTOGRAPH. In it we see a WOMAN posing with a BABY. He shows her.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Eleven months. My wife says yesterday he points up, says daddy. You have three, ya?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: A girl and two boys, twins.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You must miss them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s only a few days. And -- you know -- they’re here with me. She points to her head.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Their voices. Get it done, mom. Make us proud. Over the PA we hear:

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Morning Discovery this is Houston control. Laura stands, chit chat over.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Go time.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laura that song was from your family who hope you have a wonderful space day today. She tags the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Roger, Houston CMS. Standby.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Discovery crew messages are on board and printing. If you can work it in, we’d like to get post sleep cryo config performed in the next 15 minutes or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger Houston. Starting sequence. Calling 02 first. Hydrogen second. Laura navigates a dizzying array of panels and switches.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tank one, 816. T2 813. Tank 3 816. Tank four 814. T5 814. Manifold pressure optimal. H2. Tank one 212 -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MAIN HATCH - “DAY” Laura stands in her space suit with Hank and COLE. Hank reaches for the airlock control. He pushes the button. The hatch opens.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLANET EARTH
dialogues.text: As it is revealed by the retreating door, oceanic, bathed brilliance.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: As celestial light hits her. The view is indescribable. Despite her professional demeanor, Laura can’t help but t in the magesty of the universe.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SPACE SHUTTLE DISCOVERY - “NIGHT” Laura, Hank and Cole put finishing touches on the panel s repairing. It’s dark now, the sun hidden on the other sid the Earth. Below her, the NEON LIGHTS of the Shanghai night GLOW and PULSE, reflecting off her visor.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Okay. Last bolt. He fastens it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's it, folks. Time to pack up and go home.  7. The three astronauts process that, the end of the mission Beat.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe five more minutes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's fine with her. She doesn’t want this trip to end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew is strapped in for the return to Earth.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKLE
dialogues.text: ISS Decouple complete.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I have the stick. Beginning descent. He fires thrusters and begins their break from orbit. We PAST the PILOT and CO-PILOT and move towards Laura, sitti in back. Her job is done. Around her, the crew is talking laughing. Laura stays focused, a tool without a task. She tries to on to the feeling, to remember every moment, to slow time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the SHUTTLE descends from outer space, encounters atmospheric resistance, it’s tiles beginning to heat up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue skies, just high enough to see the curvature of the Earth. BOOM BOOM. The distinct double-thunderclap of the sonic boom that accompanies every Space Shuttle as it re-enters earth’s atmosphere, racing through the sky at 6,000 miles per hou BOOM BOOM.  The loud rumble of the Discovery crew out-running sound itself can be heard all across the Gulf Coast. The belly of Discovery glows BRIGHT LAVA-ORANGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMMANDER LYNCH, steady hands at the controls, eases the orbiter into its descent to the Eastern coast of Florida. Laura, focused, attentive, monitors the onboard safety systems. The noise is deafening but the crew hammers on.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: There she is. Through the windshield we see CAPE CANAVERAL, Runway 33 straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gear down. They make their approach to Cape -- the ground closing in fast -- and TOUCH DOWN on the hard macadam like clockwork

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chutes. A button is pushed. PARACHUTES rocket from the rear of the orbiter. The astronauts are thrown forward against their restraints, a the G force of the fast brake kicks in. Discovery rolls to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well done, astronauts. They unbuckle.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go home. Laura removes her restraints, rising slowly. We notice al the astronauts move sluggishly, feeling the effects of gravity for the first time in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: Ugh. Earth sucks.  Qo They move out of the cockpit, into the MAIN HOLD and towa the exterior door. Hank claps Cole on the shoulder, grinn Ahead of us, the SHUTTLE DOOR is opened, sunlight pouring The cabin around Laura goes dark. From her POV we approach the doorway -- the darkness arou the doorway closing our frame from 2:35 to 4:3. Laura ent frame and -- EXITS THE SHUTTLE onto the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in full daylight, we realize we’re still in the shrun aspect ratio -- as if back on Earth Laura’s life is small somehow, more claustrophobic.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: as she blinks against the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: THE RUNWAY
dialogues.text: A LARGE CROWD is gathered on bleachers, NASA personnel, families and the general public. HANK waves to the crowd, as do the other astronauts. They celebrities for a day, American heroes.

dialogues.speaker: THE CROWD
dialogues.text: We see DREW WALLACE (40s) and the kids. Drew is a NASA pu relations executive. He’s a handsome guy with a good smil who worships his wife.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: (points) There she is. There’s mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks a little stunned at the change of focus -- from mission to celebration. An hour ago she was on the International Space Station, hundreds of miles above the Earth. She works up a smile, waves. NASA boiler suited WORKERS approach and help the crew to flag draped stage. Hank takes an offered MICROPHONE.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Cape Canaveral!  10. Thunderous applause. The crew can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This bird was in the best shape of any I’ve flown. We did it. We’1l do it again. Darn it, we’re gonna be doing it for a heck of a long time. The crowd goes nuts. Laura deals with gravity, squints.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also -- to the crew and family of the Columbia -- we miss you every day -- let’s have a moment of silence. Everyone on the stage and in the crowd goes silent, bows their heads. A long beat as we see the faces in the crowd including Laura’s family. HANK looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. We’1ll go say hi to our own families now. Y’all have a great day. The ceremony ends. Laura makes her way off the stage a li shakily. Below on the runway, her family awaits.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: There’s my girl. Laura’s daughter RUTH (15) is a few paces away. Laura’s twins, NEIL and ED (6), hold foil “Welcome Home” balloons They see her, and --

dialogues.speaker: MOM
dialogues.text: -- come running for her, arms outstretched, their BALLOON flying away. Even Ruth is tearing up. The boys hit their mother at full speed--

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: -- Oof. Laura bundles them into her arms. Kisses every smiling fa Drew puts his arms around Laura. She leans into him.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: We missed you so much. He gives them all a big hug that lifts her off the ground

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful. I might break. Laura at the centre of a bundle of her family looks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: As the balloons float up and up towards the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. FRANK PAXTON’S OFFICE. CAPE CANAVERAL, FL - LATER Laura waits as Paxton thumbs through a flight report. His office is a museum to the last 30 years. Photos of his identical haircut over years, overseeing construction of prototype ENTERPRISE, posing with SALLY RIDE, JOHN GLENN

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: So. How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Walking’s more of a pain in the ass than I remember.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Get’s easier. How was it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: That’s not what I asked.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Best two weeks of my life. Paxton smiles up from his paperwork. For all his work he’ never been to space. This is as close as he’ll ever get.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boat ran like a clock. Systems held up. Crew were top class.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: There'll be a routine psych follow up at 3 days, 14 and 30 to 45 — just to go over lessons learned in hindsight and help you adjust to your new role on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s not necessary.  12.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Well, it’s regulation, so -- any confusion up there? Panic?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'll admit, first time you step out of that bay -- it’s not nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Did you feel any immediate danger?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We all took the same risk.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Laura considers, wanting to give an honest answer.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sir, I never felt so alive. Paxton smiles. He sits back from his desk.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: I’1l be honest, I don’t know how many more of these launches we’re gonna do.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That’s a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: I know, but -- a lotta suits in Washington think our budget’d be better spent elsewhere. Bombs maybe. But in the meantime, Atlantis is around the corner for us --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: -- Two years to blastoff, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: And we'll need a Mission Specialist. Would you be willing to return? Laura has to stop herself from blurting out: ABSOLUTELY.  3h

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I hope to serve NASA and my country any way I can for as long as I can.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WAITING ROOM. PAXTON’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Paxton escorts Laura into a waiting area, where a MAN lea against the wall and thumbs through an old issue of Time.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: You’re one of the good ones, Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- not what you said when I got back. The man smiles, MARK GOODWIN, a 45-year-old All-American with an edge of surfer.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: That oughta tell you something. You met Mark Goodwin? In from Houston. He’s the driver seat for the Endeavour launch. (to Mark) Our other pilots are all busy that day huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I believe every single one, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (offers her hand) Laura Wallace. Wow. You go -- January 27th right? Congrats.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: An honour to serve. How was it? He points up and whistles an ascending note. Laura laughs

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Amazing. He stares at her. No sale. She’s wrong footed. The moment hangs. It’s awkward. Laura draws breath to speak when --  14.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok, there it is.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sorry. There what is?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Plain as day.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Commander Goodwin has a “theory” he can tell who’s been to space by looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: More than a theory, chief. Laura is a little thrown. Mark sees her self-consciousnes

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s OK. Coming back is hard.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Teel Laura throws a nervy glance at Paxton. Mark sees and smil

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Already trying to get back there, aren’t you? You go get ‘em, tiger. He throws a loose salute and walks away. She watches him All the way. Laura snaps out of a daze to see Paxton disappearing --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Wait, sir? Where do I report to now? He shrugs re-entering his office.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Nowhere. Go home with your family. Month paid leave starts now.  5 Laura tries to return his grin but doesn’t quite manage i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wallace SUV heads home.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm saying it’s a choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew drives. Laura is in the passenger seat. The kids are back. Laura looks out the window, taking in her return -- trees, houses. But also trash on the side of the road. Al the problems of mankind, right where she left them.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You're either -- the kind of person who sees problems, or you see solutions. Ed and Neil bicker in the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: They kicked him outta school. What’s the spin there?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: He’s not my -- he’s Jenny’s boyfriend and he got expelled for blowing up a toilet with a cherry bomb. Turn that into a public relations win.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Well, maybe your school was the wrong school for him. Maybe this is the push he needs to get his act together. See? The glass is half full, not half empty.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What do you think, mom?  16.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I think the glass is too big.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Your mom’s an engineer. Laura turns in her seat, explains.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: See, if you got a glass that’s only ever filled half way, you've got more glass than you need to get the job done. The kids look at her like she’s from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: A CEILING FAN
dialogues.text: dissolves in over her face, spinning in the Texas heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Drew (dressed) lay on top of the made bed, look up. Laura’s packed bags are in evidence by the closet. We hear sound of life from the rest of the house.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The azaleas look good.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I watered them every day. (beat) Or I would have, if I didn’t forget. Those are new. I put em in this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Yeah? (beat) Babe, we went to space. He looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m so proud of you.  Lie

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It was -- I don’t know -- it’s hard to put in words.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I bet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: To be up there.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Did you see the Great Wall of China? How about Texas? See us waving up from the back lawn? -- Ed runs past their doorway screaming, a LIT SPARKLER i his hand. Drew sits up.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ed Wallace! Freeze, boy. Get back here. Ed tromps back into the bedroom, sad-faced now, the spark still burning.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never bring a lit anything into this house? Not a candle, not a match -- certainly not a firework.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sparkler.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You know the rules, boy. Bed. Now. Ed looks like he might cry.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I did miss the 4th. Ed looks up, sensing an opening.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You get sparklers up there?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not even one. (whispers) Maybe you and me ought to do something about it. Don’t tell Dad. Got any more where this came from? Ed has a giant smile across his face.  18. -- KA-BOOM-- FIREWORKS EXPLODING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the home-variety but it’s still an impressive display. -- A LIT FLAME LIGHTS FUSES -- as Laura runs around light mortars, black cats, cherry bombs. The twins look on in a Drew pulls Ruth to a safe distance.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: -- I’m being careful.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Laura, that’s too close!- -- POP POP POP POP -- inches from her face, a series of bottle rockets spray off in all directions -- LAURA YELLS DELIGHT. Everything SLOWS DOWN, the fireworks becoming abstract. I the darkness we might not notice the EDGES OF FRAME WIDEN as the fire light becomes --

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEMENTAL INFERNO OF A SHUTTLE BOOSTER AT LIFT OFF --
dialogues.text: and we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now back in WIDE SCREEN. Laura is pressed into her seat a Discovery lifts high from the ground. She yells into the helmet. Fighting real pain. Pressure three times gravity pins her head. A deafening rattle grows louder and louder, swallowing all sound. In corner of her eye she sees HANK, fighting to hit a switch

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Separation in three! Two -- There’s a lurch forward as Discovery’s solid rocket boost decouple and fall, slowing the orbiter’s momentum. Brief respite as Laura is pinned to her seat as thrusters engag She grimaces. If the vibrations don’t shake the shuttle t pieces they might her. It slows. Sheer hell recedes. In a cabin window, day gives way to night in seconds, rea life on timelapse as Laura breaks past the edge of the wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She floats. She can breath again. Tears fill her eyes. She looks out of the window at stars Outside, A SINGLE FIREWORK detonates. Its bloom filling t view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparkling fireworks fade into the night sky. With the fad the edges of the screen shrink back to 4:3. WE FIND Laura leaning on the house, staring up. She sips beer. Drew works the grill.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Y'all done burning down the subdivision? We are almost eating here -- Ruth, texting on her phone, ignores the family.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hey. Come over here.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Pourquoi?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just do it missy. Ruth stomps to her mom. Laura pulls into her, wrapping bo her arms around, resting her chin on top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you grow while I was gone?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: How could that even be possible? You were gone like a week?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thirteen days thanks for counting. Wait. What did I miss? Spill. Laura tickles her daughter who fights her off but there’s hint of a smile on Ruth’s lips. It'd disappear in a secon anyone could see. Laura kisses her and relents into a hug

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Dad killed your azaleas and bought new ones from Lowe's. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ed got mad coz they’1ll never name a hurricane after him. Neil ate five popsicles and puked in the yard.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I meant with you. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Me? Well. I had my first period.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh my god! Ruth!!?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: And I got a man-friend. He got me pregnant coz of the whole new womb sitch so I'll prolly get anorexic about that. Gonna get into drugs this weekend to cheer myself up. Oh I’m totes gay. So no wedding, chill? Ruth pecks her mother on the cheek and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So long as you’re happy. (beat) You were joking about the thing right? Laura gestures south. Ruth disappears back into her phone

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Rad heart-to-heart, mom. Nailed it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know I missed you, right?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. Laura wanders in, wearing her bathrobe, looking groggy. Drew is dressed for work, a “NASA Public Relations” I.D. around his neck, slurping cereal.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hi, sleepyhead. How’s rocket lag?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What time is it? Where’re the kids?  2ye

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Half eight. Carpool picked ‘em up. I better be going too -- Drew sets the bowl in the sink past Laura, kiss on the ch

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- we're almost done cutting all the footage together from the mission. I’ve got Commander Lynch coming in later to start the interviews for the press kit. Not all on vacation you know.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know how I love a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You earned it. Enjoy. You OK?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Getting used to -- stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I get it. Just rest. Mission accomplished. My hero. He kisses the top of Laura’s head and leaves for work. La stands in her pajamas in the middle of her kitchen. Maroo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it. She can’t just sit around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An upscale old folks home situated on a golf course. We F AN OLD WOMAN sitting on her first floor patio, a low pati wall between her and the links. She has the nasal plugs o OXYGEN line in her nose. This is MIRIAM “NANA” HOLBROOK, materfamilias, a woman who can do the Sunday Times crossw puzzle in under an hour and then kill a rattlesnake with shovel. As we watch Nana raises a cigarette to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: There are better ways to kill yourself than smoking with your oxygen machine. Nana turns. Laura is there, holding a tool box.  220

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: How's that, fucker? Laura kisses her Nana on the head, sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, I’m back.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: (teasing) Did you go somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Up, then down. Beat. Nana smokes.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: You show those Ivy League assholes how it’s done?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Damn straight. Beat. They watch the golfers.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: (beat) Your father played golf. Said it was good for business.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He was unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: He was an idiot. (looks over) You here to make sure I’m still breathing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Drew said your disposal’s out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NANA’S APARTMENT. ASSISTED LIVING FACILITY - DAY Laura lays on the floor, her head and arms buried in the cabinet under the sink. She’s working the disposal with a screwdriver.  23).

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m supposed to be on vacation. I’ve already color coded three rooms in my house and signed up for six school committees. Nana sits on a red scooter, watching. She pours some whis in her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: You should get a hobby, like me.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Drinking’s not a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Well, government says I’m too old to do it professionally. Laura comes out from under the sink, wipes grease on her pants.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Fixed. She stands, goes to wash her hands.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: They giving you a medal?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: NASA? For what? All I did was my job.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Good girl. No special treatment. When’s the next mission?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Endeavour goes in a few weeks. Atlantis is in two years. That’s my shot. Beat. Nana studies her.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Well, you’re not getting any younger. Laura nods.

dialogues.speaker: NANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So you're just gonna have to work harder.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura runs hard on the training facility’s outdoor track, behind her looms the gigantic SATURN V ROCKET, casting a shadow over the track in the afternoon sun. She's suddenly aware of a shadow gaining on her from behi A young woman, tall, athletic, ERIN ECCLES (20s) wearing NASA CADET tracksuit pushes past her, apparently without effort. Laura watches her pull away. On the next lap the same girl is doing “clap up” press up the grass by the track. Controlled. Strong. Easy. With a burst of energy, Laura sprints. It’s intense, ugly running - pushing the limit. She doubles over, sweat pour

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Relax. You’ll run faster. Mark jogs past. Laura tries to speak between breaths. Fai

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Loose. No hurry. Just -- let go. Mark rips into an fluid upright sprint action. We linger her. As Mark disappears at impressive speed, he bellows:

dialogues.speaker: KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK
dialogues.text: -- at a comical volume. Laura laughs, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits in the SUV, doing pickup like a regular parent She watches the daily routine of other families.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: And their parents, pickups by foot and by car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how civilians do it -- leisurely, like there’s al the time in the world, like nothing else exists in the universe, not even death. To calm herself, Laura begins to mutter a checklist.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: UTS to urine transfer hose. Closed. Connect urine tranfer filter to faeces PD. Check.

dialogues.speaker: HER BOYS
dialogues.text: Coming out the front doors.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: not seeing them, focused on the checklist. We PUSH IN on face.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clip receptical ASSY to transfer hose. Check. URA valve. Vent. Open. AROUND HER the car disappears, replaced by the INTERNATIO SPACE STATION.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Lost in the moment, triple checking her space suit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Management drain valve. Dump. Flush PKG, screen and honeycomb. Check. There is a PORTAL WINDOW beside her. Halfway through the checklist she pauses, turns, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: TWO ASTRONAUTS
dialogues.text: tethered and floating outside, framed by the Earth’s atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY --
dialogues.text: THE REAR DOORS of the SUV OPEN, the boys climbing in. Lau starts at the noise, turns.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Hey, mom.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Hey.  26.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hey, guys. How was -- sorry -- how was school today? Ed leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: What’s a cocksucker?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BOY’S ROOM. WALLACE HOUSE. HOUSTON, TX - NIGHT The boys are asleep in their beds. We FIND LAURA in the doorway. She studies them. Over their beds are mobiles of planets. All their toys are space toys, the posters on th wall. Laura studies the planets spinning above their beds on th mobile. She goes down the hall. Music comes out of Ruth’s room. The door is open a crack. Laura looks in.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: She's on the bed, Facetiming with a friend. She laughs, happy. She looks up, sees her mother -- sticks out her tongue, but playfully.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She waves. She should be happy, but she feels outside of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Drew are in bed. They make love.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She loves her husband. She’s trying to be present.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Above her, absorbed, worshipping her. The EDGES OF FRAME vibrate around him, trying to burst free, to open up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She gives herself to the act -- trying to fake it till sh makes it.  Blo The world around them opens slightly, and for a moment it seems Laura will escape her head, but then DREW FINISHES The walls close in again. He rolls off her, breathing hard, snuggles up.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I missed you, pooh bear. He closes his eyes. Laura lays beside him, looking at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And you're settling back in?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WILL PLIMPTON’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - DAY Laura sits across from Will Plimpton, the Nasa psychiatri

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Never settle. My Nana taught me that.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: (beat) How are you feeling physically?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm in top shape, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: After just a few days in zero gravity your bone and muscle mass begin to shrink dramatically. You were up two weeks. I’ve seen men carried off the shuttle, too weak to stand. Laura stands, showing him she’s fine. PLIMPTON (CONT’D) Frank told me you graduated top of your class from the naval academy, valedictorian in both high school and college. I guess my question is -- can you stop?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Stop what?  28.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Working.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m an astronaut with three kids. When exactly am I supposed to stop?

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Aren’t you on paid vacation right now? (she nods) And didn’t I see you on the track here yesterday, and in the gym this morning?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Bone density. Muscle mass.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Throw a frisbee. Fly a kite. Laura laughs at a private thought. PLIMPTON (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My Nana says frisbees are for dogs.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Tell me about her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Miriam Holbrook -- fifth generation west Texan, Daughter of the American Revolution -- husband died in a drilling accident, raised three kids by herself, got her engineering degree at night.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: So -- tough. Beat. Laura thinks about that. To her Nana is just what a woman needs to be. No adjectives necessary.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Three guys chased my dad home from school one day with axe handles. She put the first warning shot in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: The first.  297.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: In Texas a leg shot’s considered a warning.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: (beat, then) Why were they chasing him?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Your dad.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He pissed in the gas tank of their car. Beat. They think about that -- where she got her drive an strength, because it wasn’t from her father.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Take a walk, go to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I will. He studies her. She’s lying.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: Michael Collins.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Apollo 11. He piloted the moon lander that delivered Neil and Buzz.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: So you know that after he dropped them, he circled the moon for hours, farther from Earth than any man has ever been -- no light, no radio. And he wept, consumed by darkness, and then -- when he saw the sun again -- he wept some more. Inside the capsule he wrote: I am now truly alone and absolutely alone from any known life. I am it. Beat. What can she say to that? The words are like live w she doesn’t want to touch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m fine.  30.

dialogues.speaker: PLIMPTON
dialogues.text: You need rest -- and time. To process what happened. To ground yourself. Literally.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: As she thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura carries a tray to a table. She is hailed by everyon she walks -- a returning hero. She approaches FRANK PAXTO He is standing with ERIN ECCLES the young woman from the running track. If Laura is the Terminator, Erin is the T-1000; newer, faster, more cunning. But she’s also kind, hopeful, an optimist. Paxton sees Laura.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Wallace, got your sea legs back?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: This is Erin Eccles. She’s training for the Atlantis mission. Erin sticks out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: It’s an honor. Laura shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I saw you on the track this morning.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You need to keep your head up.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I'll -- thanks for the tip.  Say

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Laura’s in the running for Atlantis too.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Can't beat experience. Beat. Laura holds Erin’s eye, but Erin doesn’t back down. Paxton sees the tension, doesn’t try to defuse it.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Okay, well -- good luck to you both. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: He seems like a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: A real pro.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: So what's it like up there? Must be quite a rush.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s a job, kid. Not kite-boarding off Kuai. Remember that when you're on a three axe spin at four G's.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Thanks. Do you think maybe -- I don’t know -- I could call you sometime for advice? This takes Laura off guard. She softens.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Great. Do you have a cell phone, granny, or are you still on a land line? Beat. Laura smiles. Fuck you, too.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Chin up. Laura walks away, finds a table, pushes her food around, watching Erin wander over and mingle with a GROUP OF MEN. she flirting?  320

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Moonglow. Laura looks up. Mark is standing there with two young gir CHELSEA and EMILY, 9 and 6.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m giving my ladies a tour. Chelsea, Emily, this is Laura. She’s a colleague of Daddy's.

dialogues.speaker: CHELSEA
dialogues.text: Are you an astronaut?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Laura smiles, shooting a friendly salute. They salute bac

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great to meet you. Your Dad’s always telling everyone how cool you are. They're thrilled to hear this. Mark mouths a “Thank You”-

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You know girls, Laura here was in space last week. Maybe you’ve got a question for her? Laura smiles as they struggle to come up with anything --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Uhm --

dialogues.speaker: CHELSEA
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that brownie?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Over there. And they’re so good. Mark offers five bucks which they snatch and go running:

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Don’t tell mom you ate that! (to Laura) Separated. It’s a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They seem like great kids.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They are. Do you bowl?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Bowling. Indigenous cultural praxis of the North Americas? Promotes social cohesion via pointless competition, alcohol abuse and shared footwear. -- Mark eats the end of her brownie. She notices.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: With you and the girls?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: With the club. You’re a member now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What club? Mark flags two astronauts passing by. He points both fing

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Roll tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yep. Mark points to Laura and looks expectant --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What _ club?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: The most select group formed in the history of mankind. Mark solemnly taps a patch on his flightsuit. A rolling E scatters tenpins, NASA and CRB embroidered above and belo

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A secret society where every member has been to heaven to look upon the face of God. The one. The only: Circle of the Rolling Ball. Laura waves him off laughing --  Just then, 34.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Fun as that sounds -- I’m not really a joiner. Plus kids and blah blah -- dinner don’t make itself.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Earth families. You got a new family now. Semper volvens.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You want me to say that to my husband? That -- bad latin.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Tell him it’s training. That’s what the rest of us do. Emily and Chelsea return, with a tray of desserts.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sugarlanes 8pm. Ask for Wernher von Braun. (to her kids) Girls, lets go see if we can eat this riding a centrifuge. C’mon -- Mark grabs the tray and bails leaving Laura shaking her h

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LAURA’S SUV. HOUSTON, TX - NIGHT Laura behind the wheel, phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (on the phone) What training? You’re not supposed to be back yet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know. I told them. But it’s just - - simple stuff. More of a debrief. I won’t be late.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, if it’s good for NASA, I guess it’s a win for me too.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. She hangs up.  35r REVEAL: Her car is parked outside SUGARLAND LANES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It arcs through the air, landing on a waxed lane headed i the triangle of hope -- -- CRASH -- pins tumble and spin leaving a badly split sp

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Darn it. By the ball return, Mark pals around with Pete and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Trajectory apex error.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I like the challenge. Make it a little fairer on you boys. Laura takes a swig from a Yuengling. Mark brandishes her

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Depends. You got any idea what you're talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: My great grandfather invented this game. Swear to god. Great great. Mark close to Laura, cupping her hand in his-- AND DRAWS arm back in large, slow practice throws.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Secret is -- little twist at the end there. You see? Laura feels the closeness of his body. They move together

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Lil’ twist? You coach the boys like this, that the secret in this club?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: We ask him not to. Gets so weird.  36.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Help us. Can you?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: The secret is he’s hammered.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s no secret at all. Mark heads to his beer but not before calling out to Laur

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember what I told you! Laura steps up to the line. She takes a deep breath befor heaving the ball down the lane and -- PICKS UP THE SPARE! The astronauts go berserk. Laura rains high fives.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on. Say it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: All student, no teacher.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I like it. I’1l take that. And now “the Teacher” steps up. Gathers. Mark grabs a ball, winds up -- flexes wildly and slides t the line. Hurls the rock where it soars and-- -- skews hard into the gutter. Mark holds his perfect for

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And shake hands with the kingpin. Laura and the guys fall about laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: LATER -- the astronauts shoot the shit post-game. Laura notices Mark up at the bar making the barmaid laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: How you doing since you got back?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Tongue still feel weird?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: YES! What is that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows. They think the brain adjusts to speaking in zero G. Goes in about a week.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m great. Pretty great. Feel a little like -- I don’t know. Y'know? The astronauts nod in unison.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: You crack up yet?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Not a question of if, just when.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How hard.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Wait -- what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Saying watch yourself for the first few months. You saw what few people ever see. Felt things no one feels. Don’t go walking around pretending you're like everyone else and life is what you always thought it was.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Because you’1ll lose your shit. Plus it isn’t the truth. Is it? Laura stares levelly back at them. She opens a fraction.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Beats the shit out of me. S/o  38.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Me too. And yet, here we all are. Right here. No place else.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Right now. No time else.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Just like we all saw. Right? Mark swings in, placing an armful of beers on the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: As requested: five Yuenglings.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And four of us, Professor.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: How could this have happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARK AND PETE AND JIM IN UNISON
dialogues.text: Must’ve been a rounding error. Laura laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That’s why he likes you so much. You laugh at his old jokes.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Only old joke here is you, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Come on. We love each other.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I assure you, we do not.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Then how come we shared all the sordid details of our entire lives?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ooh sordid details? Like what?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I could have done without it.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Me too. Some of that stuff --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: C’mon. Spill.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’m a saint.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh you are, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: A saintly man and a manly saint. St. Mark of the Star Filled Sky.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yup. He’s a -- what he said. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark’s truck rolls up the driveway. Mark bails to the passenger side, making an exaggerated bow --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And a gentleman. Laura laughs, returning the gesture with a regal nod. On way out of the truck, Laura SLIPS, falling onto Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Still working on those Earth legs?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Or just intoxicated. Laura regains her footing, bracing against Mark. She look at her house, lets out a wistful sigh. Mark nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You don’t know what to tell them. That’s OK. You can’t. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (realization dawning) They’11 never know.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You’re lucky here. Remember that. Might not seem like it. But you are. They need you. You need them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you ever stop missing it?  40.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I wish I could lie, but I can’t. You can turn away and hide, but I’m afraid there’s nothing like it. Laura is suddenly aware it’s unclear whether he means spa NASA or a house with a family waiting. They’re inches apa

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I better go. Mark nods, stepping back. Laura heads unsteadily inside.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: See you on deck, sailor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura enters the house, dropping her bag on the kitchen f and slowly, quietly making her way up the stairs. As she moves down the hallway, she notices a light still on: Rut

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. RUTH’S BEDROOM. WALLACE HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Laura finds her asleep, hand marking place in a Harry Pot Laura carefully dog-ears her page. Puts the book away. As she watches her daughter sleep, Laura chokes up sudden overcome with emotion. Desperate. She crouches down hugging her knees and looks up at Ruth’ ceiling, covered in glow-in-the-dark plastic stars and he huge silent sobs as her daughter softly sleeps. We hear:

dialogues.speaker: NASA SUIT SPECIALIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: TWR Jett.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Auto. Down. Guarded.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Laura stands suited up in the centre of a incredibly brig lit room attended by ENGINEERS and suit specialists readi checklists to her from clipboards.  41.

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: The engineers speak very fast.

dialogues.speaker: NASA SUIT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: EMER cab press valve.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Check and check.

dialogues.speaker: NASA SUIT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: Suit CKT return valve.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Open.

dialogues.speaker: NASA SUIT SPECIALIST 2
dialogues.text: Reverse 02 umbilicals.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA NASA SUIT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: Suit Power. Check. Suit Power.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA NASA SUIT SPECIALIST 2
dialogues.text: Audio con. Normal. Audio control.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA NASA SUIT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: Connect Comm Con Head to PGA. Connect Comm Control Head t Check. PGA. The engineers start laughing as Laura get’s ahead of them without a clipboard or needing any prompting. Continues a

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: UTS to urine transfer hose. Closed. Connect urine tranfer filter to faeces PD. Check. Clip receptical ASSY to transfer hose. Check. URA valve. Vent. Open. Management drain valve. Dump. Flush PKG, screen and honeycomb. Check. Check. And Check. Stop the clock. Done and done. Laura puts her hands in the air in victory laughing. Whoo

dialogues.speaker: NASA SUIT SPECIALIST
dialogues.text: All other crew hate checklists so much they want to kill us by now.  42.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You kidding? Gotta love a checklist- (stage whispers) Maybe they’re just lazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura, Mark, Hank and Erin --in astronaut gear-- strapped into a shuttle simulator that’s nearly as old as they are A machine built in the 70’s -- slow and prone to breaking down. The astronauts busily check their instruments as --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Error 143B. Check life support. Sirens. Erin yanks a Mission Protocols binder. Flips thro

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Copy that. Houston, Endeavour reporting LSS crew cabin warning.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Roger Endeavour, confirm 02 level?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: 02 solid. Power essential busses?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: ESS1BC, ESS2CA and ESS3AB reading confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Houston, do you read? DC and 02 seen and green.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Copy Endeavour. Sirens and blinking warning lights continue. Laura winces

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Still a lot of Christmas up here.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: PRS restart indicated Houston?

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Endeavour CAPCOM is a hard restart.  43. Erin’s thumbing through a second binder. A second, more staccato siren begins SHRIEKING.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Need action here, Eccles.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Almost there --

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: 02 dropping. Venting fast. Erin is throwing switches on her console. No luck.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Eccles?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’m -- gimme a second.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We don’t have a second, rookie. Erin focuses, finds it, flips a series of switches on her console -- flashing lights and sirens suddenly STOP. Everything still.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Got it. Beat. They wait, then --

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Green lights. All systems go. End drill. Mark takes off his headseat.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Nice work, legs. Well -- who’s hungry? Mark unbuckles his harness, strolls out of the simulator.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: She's breathing hard, exhilarated. She looks over at Laur who frowns. Erin gives her a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura walks down a busy NASA hallway. She stops at one do that’s slightly ajar. She turns 180. Walks away. Get’s a feet down the corridor -- stops. She looks back.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTRE - DAY KNOCK KNOCK. Laura pokes her head in to see -- -- Mark, fast asleep at his desk. The tinny sounds of Ste Dan coming from an early iPhone on his desk. Laura closes the door quietly and walks over to him. She leans close, getting just inches from his face-- -- and SLAMMING HER HAND ON HIS DESK-- Mark startled awak gasps a big, shocked breath. Laura laughs. Mark plays coo

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I’m awake. I am. Wide awake.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What you doing for lunch? Mark places a paper bag on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Got a packed lunch. She reaches into the bag, pulls out a SIX-PACK OF BUDWEIS

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s late notice but I could see if the maitre D has a table for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura’s SUV parked on a SIDE ROAD in the Johnson Complex. decommissioned Saturn V Rocket visible from her windshiel Inside, Mark and Laura split an order of fries. Mark pops top of a can of beer; hands it to Laura. As she sips, a car drives by. Laura repositions to hide t fact she’s drinking. Mark laughs at Laura’s cautiousness.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s like we’re back in high school smoking under the bleachers.  45. Mark takes a big swig from his can.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You never smoked under no bleachers. Uh uh.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You're a straight arrow. You never did a wrong thing in your life.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I've done plenty of things wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I bet you never even came second. Beat. It’s true.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Know-it-all, I done plenty of tawdry shit, I’m here to tell ya --

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hit me. Laura thinks for a moment but she is genuinely stumped.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about -- smoking under the bleachers?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Nope. Never did that. Mark laughs and takes another sip. He stares out the passenger window and sighs. He suddenly seems very lost.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Yeah. My kids -- (sighs) -- none of this is easy. Laura nods. She thinks. Then --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The other night the guys were talking about being in orbit --  46.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You felt it right? Up there. Laura stops. This is a step out of her comfort zone.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Felt what?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You tell me. Maybe you didn’t. She searches for words to describe the indescribable.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Like being blasted completely apart and put back together and instantly I felt like -- I felt like --

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You understood it all.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yes. Oh my god. Yes. What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: A sense that everything’s a part of everything else. All separation between things is illusion.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Out of nowhere. I was looking down. I realized -- I realized --

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You realized who you are and why we're all here. Right? We’re the fringe that feels. Laura is suddenly wide open. She leans and KISSES HIM, fu and deeply -- just as quickly, she pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: God I’m so sorry. I can’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What are we doing? We’re just kids smoking under the bleachers. He leans and kisses her. Laura kisses back. More passiona than the first. She reaches for his belt. They pull at ea other. Urgent. Hungry. Unstoppable. As they do EVERYTHING SHAKES around them -- as if they’re strapped to a booster rocket.  47. THE EDGES OF FRAME SLIDE AWAY -- the claustrophobia of he world expanding -- the adrenaline and wonder of space returning. Mark pushes a hand down her body into her pants. She gasp Kissing deeply, Laura pushes into him. Yanking hard at hi jeans, her hands grab his bare ass. And they start to fuc

dialogues.speaker: OVERHEAD
dialogues.text: The ROOF OF THE SUV shudders, separating, the SKY reveale THEY BEGIN TO RISE out of the car, the blue sky above tur black, STARS surrounding them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA AND MARK
dialogues.text: fuck like they’re alive. Like they’re the only two people earth who are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits alone in her car. In front of her home. PANIC MODE. Convinced that what has just happened is written on face.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okey. Dokey. She forcibly releases a white-knuckle grip on the steerin wheel, trying to collect herself and spots a crushed beer in the footwell. She dives to grab it before anyone sees. She drops it in the recycling container, drops the lid an takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura enters the house like she was burgling the place --

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Mommy ! -- THE TWINS RUSH TO HUG HER, Laura puts on a brave face, desperate to look normal. Drew pecks her cheek. She wince

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hi, Mommy! Ruth wanders in.  48.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Nana’s here. Laura turns. Nana is sitting at the kitchen counter, drin scotch.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Little fuckers were just showing me their Lego.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: She said you invited her to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh shit. I, uh -- I did. I’m so sorry. She goes over, kisses Nana on the head.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: I'd slap an Okie for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Outside.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Be a doll. They’re in my purse. Laura goes into the --

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: Nana’s purse is on the hall table. Laura grabs it, but misses, knocking it over. Her wallet and cigarettes spill out, and something else -- A HANDGUN.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Seeing it. She looks around to see if anyone else saw, bu the hall is empty. She picks up the gun, holds it. A .38 special.

dialogues.speaker: NANA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling) Somethin fall on you, or you coming back?  49. Laura lowers the gun. She thinks about putting it back in Nana’s purse, but doesn’t feel comfortable with the idea. opens the coat closet, puts the gun in her jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura comes back, gives Nana her smokes.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey, how was work today?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Just -- you know -- same old. How can I help? She forces a smile at them, the happy family enjoying the normal dinner time chaos.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NASA’S NEUTRAL BUOYANCY LAB. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - An ENORMOUS WAREHOUSE that holds a SWIMMING POOL the size a football field. Underwater is a SUBMERGED SPACE SHUTTLE International Space Station. This is where NASA’s astrona train for space walks.

dialogues.speaker: CHYRON
dialogues.text: Laura’s is standing on a METAL PLATFORM, wearing a modifi underwater space suit, helmet on. The platform is lowered into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underwater Laura works a panel upside down under the ISS. Heavy suited gloves wield tethered tools with precision.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Removing thermal shroud on Rotary Joint Motor Controller on the upper face of the P3 truss. (beat, notices) Control? I got a light on suit psi regulator. Request sys error check.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONTROL ROOM. NEUTRAL BOUYANCY LAB. DAY
dialogues.text: Test director examines dozens of screens and monitors.

dialogues.speaker: TEST DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Diver SD02 move in take a look. The camera view closes in on Laura suspended in the water

dialogues.speaker: SAFETY DIVER 02
dialogues.text: I have bubbles from the helmet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She reaches a hand to the back of the helmet to investiga and pries at the joint -- bubble get suddenly worse.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Suit breach. I have a breach in the rear lateral seal. Pressure dropping. Yup, getting wet in here.

dialogues.speaker: SAFETY DIVER 02
dialogues.text: Scramble safety team. I’m going in.

dialogues.speaker: TEST DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Dive scrub. Dive scrub. Get her out of there people. The test director hits an abort button and the exit eleva moves into position. An underwater speaker sounds an alar Laura struggles with the back of her helmet trying to loc the source of the breach, she tugs at the seal and sudden water floods her helmet upside down.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Shit. SUPPORT DIVERS from all over the pool move into action, heading for Laura. Laura looks at a gauge. She speaks cal

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Suit pressure dropping. 31.8 kPa. 31.7 kPa. Steady dropoff rate. She pushes hard trying to right herself. A SINGLE LOOP of webbing from the suit to the umbilical wraps around a hid rung of handrail on the underside of the station panel. S tugs her leg. Caught.  Sir Upside down, her helmet fills with water, her eye submerg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEST DIRECTOR and TECHNICIANS anxiously converge, watching as the accident plays out live on screen.

dialogues.speaker: TEST DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: C’mon. Get her out of there. Off radio he turns to his assistant. Panic in his eyes. TEST DIRECTOR (CONT’D) Suit PSI dropping fast. Get a view from under see why she’s stationary. Over the radio Laura’s voice rings out, coolly.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Control. Got a lot of water in the helmet. Pressure’s gone. Estimated 8 seconds before I’m under here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a tangle of umbilicals and bubbles divers work to free Laura. Suit pressure is way below pool pressure, wat now pouring in. A waterline rises up the glass of her hel But Laura eyes on her watch counting seconds as they pass

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: 3 seconds. She takes a last breath. Blinks. Calm as water fills her

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m under -- -- and her mouth. Laura is now drowning. Support divers search her suit extremities for where she is stuck. Laura remains calm. Points accurately to her tethered leg A diver sees where she’s indicating. He swims down and unloops the loop of webbing. The heavy waterlogged suit starts to float freely away from the structure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAFETY DIVERS work together kicking hard with the bro suit as fast as they can towards the scaffold platform. Laura’s eyes are open. Her face peaceful. A bubble escape her nose but otherwise she is motionless. Strained. Contr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engineer calls out.

dialogues.speaker: TEST ENGINEER
dialogues.text: She’s been without 02 for two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: Laura loaded onto the elevator platform. Pulleys clank in action. Craning her out of the pool agonisingly slowly. As Laura breaks the surface divers move fast to release t suit helmet. Water gushes out of the suit. Laura gasps. Drinking air.

dialogues.speaker: SAFETY DIVER
dialogues.text: Commander Wallace. Can you hear me, Laura? Laura coughs and breathes deep. Looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Rear convolute in the restraint layer split from the bladder layer. Here. Laura holds up the section of her suit, that failed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get it fixed. Technicians work around her to extract Laura from her sui

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paxton is being briefed on the incident.

dialogues.speaker: TEST DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Watch the footage. She held her breath upside down over 2 minutes, heart rate below 120 bpm the whole time. In fact the longer it went on, the calmer she got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura on a bench. Alone for the first time. She raises he hands to her face. They’re shaking. She closes her fists. Her phone rings. DREW flashes. Laura takes a deep breath answers. Before she can say anything he is in full flow.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hon, I’ve just had the twins’ form teacher on the phone. They’re asking if you could give a talk to the kids at school next week. I’11 get a photographer from the Chronicle. The optics’ll be great for the program. Laura blinks hard, still shaking. There’s no way she can Drew what just happened in the tank.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Ok. Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Be great to give them an answer today. Can I confirm? PTA are gonna love us for this. The changing room door swings open. MARK rushes in, conce and fear on his face. Laura raises her hand to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Say yes. Listen, I gotta go. Laura ends the call.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I came soon as I heard. You OK? Mark moves to hold her. To kiss her. Laura pushes him awa Still processing near-death. Or not. Numb. Separate.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not here. I’m fine. Suit failed. Small accident. No body count.  He smiles 54.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Minutes with a pressure leak? Shit. What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What can you do? Just hold your breath and hope. Bite down.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (impressed) Bite down?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Look at me. I’m fine. Nothing wrong a dry towel won't fix. suggestively.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Well -- I’m expert rated with both beach and bath towels.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - DAY Mark and Laura are a tangle of clothes and limbs, gasping finishing a quickie up against the door. Afterwards --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's the last time, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: If you say so Commander.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We can not keep doing this.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: OK. Good. So -- OK?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Roger that. Unless -- well -- I was thinking, before I fly next month, maybe we could find some time, just us. Go away someplace.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (her heart races) Away? Where?  55.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Someplace beautiful. Beat. Laura thinks about it -- to hold onto this feeling more than just an hour, to disappear inside of it. But th

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I can’t. I can’t get the time.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Whole weekend in Florida. Just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: confused by all this -- she wants to go / she shouldn’t g She should end things. Mark sees her indecision.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t decide now. Dry out. Go home. Have a drink. None of this means anything anyway.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Look around. What do you see? A desk, a chair, the place you work. And out the window -- trees, houses -- kids on skateboards. America. You know what science sees? Protons, neutrons, electrons. He touches her chest.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this, us -- our hearts -- it’s just blood and muscle -- atoms in motion, energy being transferred. It doesn’t mean anything. So why not take our protons and electrons and go to the beach? Live.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Could it be that simple?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura runs hard, trying to keep her thoughts at bay. Ahea her she sees ERIN ECCLES, her stride easy, her form good. Laura ACCELERATES. ERIN turns, sees her coming, speeds up. The two women rac Erin’s legs are longer, but she doesn’t have Laura’s driv Slowly, but surely Laura gains on her, pulls even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strain shows on her face. She looks over, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in top shape again. If she has to, she’1ll run this bitch down for the next ten years.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: realizes this, slows, lets Laura pull ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling away. We see the triumph on her face.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LAURA’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - DAY Laura’s at her desk, annotating technical manuals. She continues reading as she opens her desk drawer and takes a small bottle. Knocks out two orange pills. Swallows col coffee and finds a card on her desk. It’s nothing special just a piece of folded over yellow paper. Inside, the card reads: “Lunch? My truck or yours?”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Mark fall back on a tangle of sheets. Laura tur to Mark, watches him as he dozes. It’s possible he’s fall asleep right there. She whispers very quietly:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I love you. I love you. I love you. -- there’s no way Mark heard it. But then --  57. -- he reaches, wraps an arm around her, and pulls her clo She pushes into him. He whispers in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I love you. I love you. I love you. Laura is ecstatic. They kiss. Like lovers in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another drill. Laura is there with Chithra and TWO other ASTRONAUTS. An ALARM rings.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL
dialogues.text: Mission fail.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Run it again.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: Laura, it’s late.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Run it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Everyone has gone to bed. Laura tip toes up the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the darkness, Laura passes by the bed where Drew is sleeping. We see he is still awake. Laura doesn’t. Drew stares into darkness. Laura goes into the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura opens the medicine cabinet. She’s tired, burning it both ends. She grabs the PILL BOTTLE, shakes out TWO MORE ORANGE PILLS, takes them. Around her, the bathroom light feels too bright. She winc squints up at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BULB
dialogues.text: The light flaring until THE SCREEN FILLS WITH WHITE LIGHT  58.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Damn, that’s bright. OUT OF TOTAL WHITE-OUT bleached facial features appear.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You OK? We are BACK IN SPACE, in widescreen, Laura floating in he space suit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's so bright. The Earth floats below her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So bright. Hypnotized, LAURA reaches up, unfastens her helmet, seduc by the view. She LIFTS OFF HER HELMET, lets it float free Somewhere in her brain she believes she can do this, beco being of pure light, celestial. She takes a DEEP BREATH, and for a second it seems like i will work -- she will transcend mortal bounds -- then her face changes. LAURA BEGINS TO CHOKE, her eyes start to bug out. Inside body, fluids begin to boil. ICICLES FORM on her eye lashe her skin turning blue. She tries to scream, but nothing comes out. As we watch she DRIFTS AWAY. We watch her go until she’s a white dot in the distance, another astral body floating through infinite space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks to his car, alone. It’s late and the place is quiet. Mark reaches his truck, opens the door and jumps -

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What the fuck? -- Laura is hiding in the footwell, waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I told Drew to go to his mom’s without me. I’m working late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks around, worried that someone might see. He hur into the truck and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You scared the shit out of me.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, I’d love to make it up to you. Laura runs her hand up Mark’s leg but he pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Not here. We're slipping. We have to be more careful.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Laura pulls away, clearly hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Let’s go to my place. He starts the engine and backs out of the parking space.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously don’t ever do that again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM. MARK’S APARTMENT. HOUSTON, TX - LATER Laura sleeps in Mark’s bed, their clothes thrown all over place. Mark leans in, whispers in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Hey. They’re gonna miss you at home

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Fifteen more minutes. I don’t think I've ever felt this good. She closes her eyes -- floating in the vacuum of the mome

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: His impatience shows. Maybe he’s not as into Laura as we thought. He shakes her lightly.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: It’s late. You should go.  She hears his tone.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, I’1l -- She sits up. He smiles at her, touches her face.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: (lying) I just don’t want you to get in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, that’s -- you’re probably right. She grabs her clothes, gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Laura creeps up to her darkened house. She takes a moment collect herself, to put her night with Mark behind her. S tries a more neutral expression. She takes a deep breath, readies herself, and enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The kitchen is a disaster. Dishes everywhere. Drew stands the middle of it all, exhausted. In an apron washing up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hey. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I've been trying you for hours --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Late night putting training modules in. I’m here. You tuck the kids in?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What time do you think it is? They're fast asleep. Laura listen --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (defensive) What? Work got harder than I thought. I just -- been a rough couple weeks y’know.  61.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Nana’s in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: She had a stroke. I’ve been trying to call you for hours. The news hits like a gut punch. Fear. Shame. Intense shoc

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: I‘1l take you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Is she OK?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Visiting hours from ten. I can take you over there, I told work I’d --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: FOR GOD'S SAKE! Stop washing the damn dishes and tell me she’s OK!

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: She hasn’t woken up -- He takes off the gloves, walks over and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you’re here, I can take you in the morning. And without any physical contact he walks up to bed. Laura stands in shock. She can’t respond to Drew’s coldne He knows? What does he know? Why is she thinking this now Laura reeling, sleepwalks to the sink. Picks up the dish put down. Suddenly she stops.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: If I’m here? -- a droplet of water begins to float upwards from the si as if suspended in zero gravity. Laura looks on as a number of droplets float up from the sink, followed by a dirty mug. She stares in terror as--  62. -- she floats upwards. Laura pushes from the kitchen coun floating through her house as if it were the innards of a orbiting ship. Tears of shock and shame float from her ey as Laura pushes her way through the darkened house. Each tear leaves her face sealed. A perfect sphere. BEEP BEEP BEEP BEEP. A hospital vitals monitor beats.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INTENSIVE CARE. HOSPITAL. HOUSTON, TX- DAY
dialogues.text: In the corridor, Drew speaks to doctors we only half see. of them. Suspended. Inside the room, Laura holds Nana’s hand. The old woman l smaller now. fragile. Tubes and machinery are all that’s connecting her to this world. Laura squeezes her paper thin hands.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
