dialogues.text: I don’t want you to worry, Nana. The doctors say you’re gonna be just fine. You just need -- (looks around, leans in) Get your lazy ass out of bed, soldier. You’re not done here. There’s still work to do. Don’t you quit on me. Nana stirs, mouths something. Laura leans closer, puts he ear to Nana’s lips.

dialogues.speaker: NANA
dialogues.text: Fucker. Laura smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew pulls the SUV onto the drive. Laura sits in silence, trying to process everything.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Did you sleep at all?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m fine.  63.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You don’t have to say that. You don’t have to --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m not fine. I’m not fine at all. There. That work for you? Does that make it all better? What? What? Drew soaks it up. He looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: That glovebox was locked. I didn’t know why so I got the key and I unlocked it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How? Wait. You got the key?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Is not the point. The point is you're driving around with a loaded gun in your car so I need to know why? You're acting so strange. I never know where you’ll be. What time you’re coming home. And now with Wally in the hospital-

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: -- you got the key off my key ring?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: A gun. In here, Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And we don’t own a handgun.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t you just ask me? Wait what did you think was in there?

dialogues.speaker: A FUCKING GUN IN OUR CAR
dialogues.text: Laura looks like this is way -- way too much for her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I had to put it someplace safe. This is hard to say out loud. Her compartments collapsing  64.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Nana’s. She had it in her purse when she came to dinner. I didn’t feel -- I didn’t want her walking around with it. Drew reaches out for her but she shrinks away from him.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me? Laura gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you ask? What did you think I was doing? Drew is open mouthed. Doesn’t know what to say. Laura wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura busies herself with a fourth or fifth load of laund sorting through mismatched socks in a manic way. Ruth enters.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Mom? Is Nana gonna be OK?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She’s pretty poorly but the doctors are taking real good care of her.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Can I come see her next time?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course. She’d like that.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I finished my American hero project for school. Want to see?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course, baby. Well done. Ruth runs off. Laura continues to fold and pile. Fold. Pi Lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ta-da.  65. -- Ruth steps into the laundry room in a flight suit. NAS patch on her shoulder, helmet under arm. She looks nervou Laura lights up. She runs to Ruth, wrapping her up in a h Ruth steps back so she can read her name badge: L.WALLACE

dialogues.speaker: RUTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pretty sick I could just do my mom.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetheart. Laura hugs Ruth tighter; she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m fine -- I’m perfect. You’re perfect. I love you so much. Laura shuts her eyes tightly as she squeezes her daughter AN ALARM SOUNDS. Laura looks up. The same as the simulator. Ruth smiles happily, walks out. Laura reaches for her but Ruth just k walking. As though she can’t hear or see anything at all. LIGHTS FLASH. The laundry room vibrates with a pulsing, hot light. Laur eyes widen. She looks around for a solution and then-- LAURA GRABS HER CELL PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S APARTMENT. HOUSTON, TX - CONTINUOUS Mark is seated at the table with his daughters as the thr of them dig into a box of delivery pizza. The place is pr sad, all boxes and the bare essentials of furniture. His phone rings: LAURA. He presses END.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: This is cool, huh? Pizza night yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searches the boxes of washing powder and stacks of towels obsessively searching for anything to turn off the klaxon Her phone again: searches email footers. MARK GOODMAN. HO

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: Chelsea and Emily laugh mouths both very full. Phone ring

dialogues.speaker: CHELSEA
dialogues.text: I got it! Chelsea leaps up and heads for the phone, but Mark stops

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Not with those grease-fingers you don’t!

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (grabs the cordless) Yello?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s me. A flicker on Mark's face -- closest we’ve seen him to los his cool. After a second, he’s got a handle on it:

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Pete. Give me a second, I'll go check on that. Girls? Daddy’s gotta find something --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MARK’S APARTMENT. HOUSTON, TX - MOMENTS LATER Mark closes the door behind him before saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: My daughters are here. They could have answered the phone. Mark looks in the window at his daughters, who are still mostly distracted by the pizza.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m a bad person. I just -- I want to tell the truth. I can’t take it. I can’t take this. I’m so alone.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Whoa. You are not a bad person. You're an incredible person. You hear me? You’re the most incredible wonderful woman I’ve ever met. And you’re not alone. I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura takes a warm towel, holds it to her face.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, you’re not.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s just too hard.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: How’s your grandmother?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: They say all we can do is wait. They said she’s stable. Thank you for asking. OK. I’m OK. (she calms) I’m sorry. Are you mad I called?

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How could I be mad when all I want is to hear your voice?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I should never call you at home. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t be. But be careful. No one can know about us. If anyone at Johnson knew --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to say it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- we'd be finished. Grounded. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: We're being careful.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Look, I’m here. I’m always here for you. Right now I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Wait there’s something else I was calling about.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Laura, what? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking about that trip - - our trip -- and I -- I can make it work? From his face we can see that he is NOT excited by this development.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Wha -- OK. Could we talk about this later?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The trip away? To someplace beautiful. I want to do it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You sure you can up and go while your grandma’s sick?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s a couple of days. 48 hours. I’1l make it work. Beat. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Laura -- I’m -- here’s the thing -- I can’t go. The launch is next week and there’s -- I’m just gonna put my head down and get in the zone. You understand, right? For a moment, Laura can’t breathe, but she pushes through - a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. Of course -- I get it. The mission comes first. Her PHONE BLOOPS, signaling an incoming call. She looks down.  69.

dialogues.speaker: THE PHONE
dialogues.text: The Caller ID reads: HOSPITAL.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. I’11, uh -- I gotta go. She switches lines.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? SFX: AN ANGRY BEEPING begins to sound, an alarm.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LAURA’S SUV (TRAVELING). HOUSTON, TX - DAY Laura drives recklessly, as the alarm gets louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura runs down the hall. We hear voices.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ten cc’s adrenaline. Prep the paddles. The ALARM SHRIEKS.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NANA’S ROOM. HOSPITAL - DAY On the bed, Nana is in FULL CARDIAC ARREST. NURSES and DOCTORS work on her, trying to save her life.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: standing forgotten in the background. She doesn’t know ho do this, to be here, to watch this fearsome woman who rai her die. WE PUSH ON HER FACE as she starts reciting a checklist.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The three essential buses are ESS1BC, ESS2CA and ESS3AB. EVERYTHING SLOWS DOWN -- death comes, inevitable, irreversible -- the cardiac team stops working, steps awa  70. LAURA blinks back tears.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The -- three -- essential -- busses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few MOURNERS stand by the grave site, a MINISTER speaki Drew has his ARM AROUND LAURA, who fights tears. WE PUSH INTO a CLOSE UP and realize Laura is murmuring something.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: ESS1BC receives power from three redundant sources.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RECEPTION after the funeral. Family friends are aroun lending support. Neil and Ed play.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sitting on the sofa with Ruth, just the two of them. Ruth crying. Laura pats her hand, staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (under her breath) DC power from fuel cell 1 through the ESS bus source FC 1 switch on panel R1 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura lays awake in bed, eyes open in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (quietly) -- when the switch is positioned to on and from main dc buses B and C We PUSH IN on her face, as NIGHT becomes DAY. She doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: THE CEILING FAN
dialogues.text: rele From her point of view. Then Drew appears. He’s got a cup coffee for her.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey, how’d you sleep?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Laid low by grief, then -- SHE BOLTS UP.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What? Laura jumps out of bed, starts dressing frantically.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s launch day.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Laura, maybe -- you can skip this one. But Laura throws on her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Can you take the kids to school?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Of course, just -- babe -- He grabs her gently, trying to slow her down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m fine. She grabs some shoes, runs out, leaving DREW to stare aft her. Over this we hear:

dialogues.speaker: EVENT ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (over the P.A.) It’s a beautiful day for a launch, seventy-nine degrees, no wind. The Shuttle Endeavor has been gassed up and she’s ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 2r EXT. BANANA RIVER VIEWING SITE. KENNEDY SPACE CENTER — DA Tourists are gathered near the large countdown clock at t Banana River Viewing Site on Cape Kennedy. Laura’s parked away from people. On the roof of her truck Nervous. She reaches in a coolbox and cracks a beer. Look her hand. One orange pill. Knocks it back with the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight Director walks the aisles of mission control, head on, listening to the calls. Pete is on command:

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: T-minus 4 minutes, stand by for readiness check.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION FLIGHT DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Roger that Command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids chase each other around. Laura watches them in the s She's chewing gum. Amped. On edge.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cooling systems: Go/no go?

dialogues.speaker: MISSION FLIGHT DIRECTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team at work, focused.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Fuel cells: go/no go?

dialogues.speaker: MISSION FLIGHT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Go.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Life support: Go/no go?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Wee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see MARK and the crew, suited up, running their final checklists.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Life support is a go. From his face we go to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura, watching the shuttle, praying for its safe launch. Tension builds. Of all people, she’s knows exactly how dangerous this is. But it’s different sitting on the othe side of the fence. Worse. Tannoy starts a direct audio fe

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh shit. It’s gonna go.

dialogues.speaker: MISSION CONTROL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Launch T-minus ten seconds. The large clock rolls backward from ten seconds. The crow gathered starts chanting numbers backward --

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Ten. Nine. Eight. Seven. Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is living every second of this. It’s agony.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Five. Four. Three. Two.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --ONE! Solid booster ignition. The countdown clock rolls to ZERO. The crowd cheer. Laura winces. Willing a skyscraper to soar. In the distan a BRIGHT FLASH of smoke and light as Endeavour'’s twin boosters ignite. The lion roar of man. She holds her brea  74.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Liftoff. We have liftoff. Endeavour arcs skyward, flame reflected on the water of t Banana River. Every inch of ascent costing Laura everythi

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Clear the tower. Clear it. Her beating heart the fuel of ascent. Inches past the tow

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go. Yes! Go. At this early hour, the booster is brighter than the risi sun. Monstrous plumes of smoke and steam, thousands of fe long billow from the launch site.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go. GO! GO!!! The small crowd thinly cheers -- how could they not? Laura -- eyes fixed on the orbiter-- starts laughing with joy of it all. She looks around herself. Marooned on her planet. No one she can share anything with. Deeply alone. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: NASA FLIGHT CONTROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Discovery’s three liquid fuel main engines now throttle back to sixty- seven percent of rated performance.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Of the DISCOVERY LAUNCH, weeks earlier. We see the main rockets firing, flames white against the blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: NASA FLIGHT CONTROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: -- reducing stress on the shuttle as it breaks through the sound barrier. We PULL BACK to FIND we are in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew moderates a panel with Laura, Hank, Chithra, Cole an Henckle. There is a mostly packed house of a hundred peop in the audience.  75.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And Commander Lynch, take us back there for you -- this was your second ride on the big slingshot, right?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yes, I flew Columbia, March 2002. (beat) Look, when you’re strapped to a ten ton rocket full of explosive jet fuel all you can do is hold on tight. On SCREEN we see footage of the astronauts in the cockpit during takeoff.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Everything -- her time in space, her Nana’s death, the intensity of the affair with Mark, and now his absence literally from the Planet Earth -- is tying her brain in knots.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And obviously, Endeavor is up there right now, circling the globe sixteen times a day. Any advice for them? Laura looks out into the audience, sees --

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Sitting in the audience, smiling at her.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, get it done and come home safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart leaps. How is this possible? Did he come back j for her? She glances at her husband. Does he see? But Drew is talk Laura turns back.

dialogues.speaker: THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Mark is gone, a STRANGER sits in his seat. It was her min playing tricks. Her hopes.  76.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And Specialist Wallace, what are you thinking at this moment? (beat) Laura? She turns.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: He nods encouragingly.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: How was take off for you?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Me? I’m -- well -- you hope everything goes well. There’s excitement. Mostly I’m just focused on the job. We don’t get much time up there. We’ve gotta make every second count.

dialogues.speaker: HENCKLE
dialogues.text: She’s the serious one.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Says the German. People laugh. Chithra speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: I‘'ll be honest. What I miss most is the team -- On SCREEN we see the ASTRONAUTS in zero gravity -- they a floating through the International Space Station -- at pl swallowing balls of water that float and rotate. CHITHRA (0.S.) (CONT’D) -- the mission, moving together, looking out for each other. There’s an AIR BUBBLE inside one of the water bubbles and acts as a camera, exaggerating people’s faces.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: watching the footage, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the crew relaxed, goofing around. The camera finds LAURA, her ponytail floating. We expect her to be the ser Laura we've seen, but she is smiling widely. The WATER BUBBLE floats between her and the camera. She m a face at it -- at us.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: watching his wife. He loves seeing her so happy. He looks over at her on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crying a little, seeing herself up there, a simpler time. What she wouldn’t give to go back.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: He assumes this is about her Nana’s death. He feels guilt It’s too soon. They should have rescheduled.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: And, uh, Laura, you had a wedding anniversary when you were in space, didn’t you? Laura wipes her face quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: How many years?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) Drew -— (beat) Seventeen years.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Must be a hellofa guy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Not bad. (to the audience) He’s my husband. They laugh.  78.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What did you do on your anniversary?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. OUTER SPACE - “DAY” We are CLOSE ON THE FACEPLATE of Laura’s HELMET. Reflecte it we see a shower of bright white dots rain across her vision in slow motion -- Her face is filled with wonder.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the event, Laura grabs her coat from the coat check Sleepless. Wrecked.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Laura? She turns to find Chithra approaching.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Hey, that was -- nice.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: Yeah. (leans in) Hey, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I'm fantastic thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: If you needed someone to talk to. I get you don’t really like me, but we shared things neither of us will ever forget. Mark Goodwin well he’s

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Sorry. What are you talking about? Chitra looks at her like -- come on. Gets nothing back.

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: Mark. People talk Laura.  vee Laura checks reflexively. DREW is standing over by the windows, schmoozing with some VIPs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Uh huh. About what?

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: Fine. Whatever. Be very careful. That’s all I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of what? What do I need to be careful of? Am I in danger here? Are you threatening me?

dialogues.speaker: CHITHRA
dialogues.text: God no. I’m trying to -- Hey, really never mind. Like for real. Jesus. She walks away. Laura is angry. Shouting after her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about. I'd never do anything as dumb as you’re insinuating. I don’t compromise myself OK? Not ever. If you know me at all. You know that. Chithra flips her the bird without turning. Laura, stares back, breathing heavy, ready to hit someone -- Drew comes over, a PR smile plastered on his face.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Hey, beautiful. Whatdya say we get you home? It’s been a long day. Laura allows herself to be led towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura, intense yet detached, is at the helm of the simula RED LIGHTS FLASH. Calmly, she turns back to the crew member responsible--

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: OK. Erin. On you.  80. A SECONDARY ALARM SOUNDS. Erin thumbs her book too quickly, missing the section.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Shit. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Stay frosty. Get it done.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I hear you. Okay. Erin starts hitting buttons. Nothing is working.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Or there’s nothing left to bury.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: For God's sake. Erin flips one last switch and -- The simulator shuts down. Failure.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: OK. Failure review. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Is not good enough. Not in any situation in here. You are not prepared. You’re poorly prepared, we fly we die. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Failure to prepare is preparation to fail.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I get it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, you don’t. This isn’t some team it’s cool to be on. We work at the edge of the possible. It never gets safe. Not ever. We win: mankind moves forward. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We lose: everybody dies. That’s the job. Show it some respect or quit. Laura unbuckles her harness and leaves the simulator.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This happens again I’m writing a formal letter requesting your RTU.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Whoa, that’s a little harsh isn’t it? Laura rounds on Erin. She's terrifying --

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Right now we're sitting in a hydrogen fire you failed to stop. H2 burns at 5500 fahrenheit. Steel is butter in a pan at half that. I’m being harsh? Am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful night for baseball. Parents and neighbor gather to watch the game. LAURA sits in the stand. Drew i his feet, cheering on his sons.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: At the plate. ED takes a lead off second base.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: calls out.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Wait for your pitch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She has her phone out. She’s typing.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: She’s WRITING an EMAIL TO MARK. My Dearest, I know you won’t get this until you come back

dialogues.speaker: THE FIELD
dialogues.text: As American boys play the national pastime under the ligh  82. We hear Laura’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was there at the take off. In the cockpit with you. In your heart. Leaving the world behind us.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: He swings at a pitch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I remember the moment I decided I had to go up there. I was nine years old. And I saw this picture -- I know you’ve seen it -- called The Pale Blue Dot. Taken by the Voyager 1 space probe from 6 billion km away.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: He claps his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Come on, slugger. He turns to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you watching?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just -- I gotta finish this review. She goes back to her note.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And the picture, all these colored lines against the night sky -- except one of the lines has a dot in it. Just a little speck. You’d miss it if you didn’t look hard. And my teacher said -- that’s us.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PLATE
dialogues.text: NEIL swings on a pitch, connects. THE BALL leaps off his bat, headed for the outfield.  83.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Us. Millions of people on this tiny blue ball. Floating in nothing. THE OUTFIELDER charges the ball, but it drops.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So precarious. So fragile. ED TAKES OFF, running for third.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And then -- to be up there. In space. More alone, more vulnerable than you've ever been in your life. THE OUTFIELDER kicks the ball. NEIL rounds first.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But instead of being afraid -- this thing rises in you. Joy. To be part of it. To see all of it. THE THIRD BASE COACH waves ED home. He runs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never felt anything like it my entire life. Suddenly everything that used to be important is nothing at all, and things you never even thought are everything to you. It’s beautiful. To be here. All of us. Every minute of our lives. All we have to do -- is be. Just be. Live it all. As real, as hard as you can. NEIL runs for second.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She hits send, her eyes watering. Drew is jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Go, go! Laura stands, as ED SLIDES, beats the throw into HOME PLA Safe. Drew grabs her, jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you see that? Did you see it? Laura smiles, wipes her eyes.  84.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I saw.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LAURA’S SUV. HOUSTON, TX - DAY Laura sits in her car, parked in the same place where she Mark first made love.

dialogues.speaker: A FLASH
dialogues.text: Of Mark and Laura in this car, a few weeks earlier. Their mouths together.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: In the present, stares at the trees rustling in the wind. The RADIO is on.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And in other news, The Space Shuttle Endeavor landed safely today, just about twenty minutes ago. Welcome home, astronauts. This one’s for you.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER FLASH
dialogues.text: Of Mark and Laura in this car, a few weeks earlier. Makin love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the present, the music playing. She hasn’t slept in da Atlantis is 18 months away. It’s just too long to wait. S needs the boost now, the rush, a sense of purpose, meanin As we PUSH IN, she makes a decision. No more half-measure She isn’t that kind of person. If you do something, you d it, commit, finish strong. She puts the car in gear, peels out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura packs a suitcase, not really paying attention to wh she takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits at the kitchen table, writing a note.

dialogues.speaker: THE NOTE
dialogues.text: Dear Drew. There’s no easy way to say this. I’ve fallen i love. She balls it up, throws it. Tries again. Kids, Mommy needs to take a little time for herself.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORNER OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Where this note too, crumpled into a ball, flies into fra and comes to rest near the first. ANGLE ON LAURA’S SUITCASE In the hall, as she grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA OVER THE CRUMPLED NOTES
dialogues.text: as she hurries out the front door with her suitcase. Her engine is revving too high. Clearly, she’s not thinking straight.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A GIANT “WELCOME HOME!” BANNER EXT. MARK GOODWIN’S BACKYARD. HOUSTON, TX - DAY Mark’s daughters are throwing a huge welcome back barbecu Kids splash in the pool, Hawaiian shirts puff cigars, pot salad and deviled eggs is unwrapped. Manning the grill is the man of the hour: Mark. Completel recovered from being in space just hours earlier.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: No. Uh-uh. Charcoal. You need twenty-two medium-sized charcoals lit in a chimney starter. 22. Let those burn to eighty percent grey and spread it evenly. I’m giving you the keys to heaven here.  86. Even Mark's estranged wife MARY seems to be welcoming the hero home. Mark reaches out, playfully swatting her ass.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t push your luck, flyboy.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: There any other way to play? Mary shakes her head, laughing and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Telling you guys, stint up there, it’s a cure-all. Lets the ladies realize how cool you are and just how much they all miss you. Who wants a burger? Everyone does, especially from an American hero. As Mark hands out charred flesh:

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Save one for me? Mark turns to find -- Laura, all dressed up and holding a potted African violet.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome home, space-boy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. GARAGE. MARK’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Mark pokes his head into the garage to make sure the coas clear before pulling Laura in with him. As soon as the do closes, Laura goes for a kiss, Mark pushes her away.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I left him.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What? Have you been drinking? Laura hands Mark the African violet as if that explains i

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s a barbecue. You’re back, I brought you this, and I left Drew so we can be together.  87. Mark looks at the potted flower in his hand, the full ext of this finally crashing down on him.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Laura, what the fuck? Laura shudders. She presses her hands to her temples.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is unbe --

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad? Emily, Mark's daughter, stands at the open door.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Sweetheart! Hey! Daddy’s just talking here OK? Be right out --

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Momma wants to bring out the cake.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: OK. Cool. Emily leaves. But the door’s open, they’re entirely expos

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You just need to leave. Now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But I --

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Right fucking now. He hands the African violet back and storms out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM. MARK’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Laura rushes through his house, on the verge of tears. Sh desperate to get out before the water works start but the house is one of those big, suburban monsters-- square foo and dining nooks at every turn. But, then-- -- there’s the door. Laura rushes for it, the potted Afri violet clutched to her chest. She’s nearly there when Eri in a cute outfit and ponytail, spots her.  88.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Laura! How about this, huh? That Mark’s something else isn’t he? Laura pushes past her, leaving a stunned Erin behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew comes home with the kids. They’ve been to the grocer store.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Okay, wash up, then come help me clean up. The kids go upstairs. Drew comes into the kitchen, puts t bags on the counter. He starts to unpack them, then NOTIC THE CRUMPLED NOTES on the floor. He goes over, picks up the first, reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face goes pale. He snatches the second note, then the third.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: comes in behind him, sees her father. Something is clearl wrong.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: AN ORANGE PILL
dialogues.text: As Laura pops it. She is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura runs hard, sweating, fleeing her demons. It is two o'clock in the morning. A SHAPE appears before her. She swerves. It’s a SECURITY GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Ma’am.  89.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I work here.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Track’s closed, ma’am. I gotta lock up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Where am I supposed to go?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: You don’t got a home?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. NANA’S APARTMENT. HOUSTON, TX - NIGHT Laura lugs suitcases into Nana’s place. It’s empty and da She drops her suitcase in the hallway and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN. NANA’S APARTMENT - EVENING Laura sits in her grandmother’s kitchen staring at the African Violet on the table in front of her. Utterly inte Nothing distracts her concentration. Not sleep. Not the sunset. Just single minded, terrifying focus. She’s doesn even blink.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BEDROOM. NANA’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Laura lies wide awake on Nana’s unturned down bed. Clothe Shoes on. She looks at the framed picture of her, Drew an the kids on the nightstand. Smiling. In love. Clock reads 4.30am. She grabs a bottle of pills from the nightstand and takes two. Lies back staring at the ceilin Tick tock, tick tock, tick tock. The BEDSIDE CLOCK is getting inside her head.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HALLWAY. NANA’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS The alarm clock FLIES out of the bedroom and SMASHES on t wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura carries the same African violet down the row of off until she reaches the door marked “GOODWIN”. Outside the door, she stops, listens: is that laughter fr inside? When she can take it no more, Laura opens the doo

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - CONTINUOUS Mark and Erin, a little too close. Mark looks up, surpris

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Heyyy! Laura?! OK. Something suspicious about Mark and Erin’s body language.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Erin’s been having a little trouble with some, uh, shut down protocols.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: She had a lot of trouble with them the other day.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I said we'd give her a few pointers

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: You’re a peach. Thanks Mark. (to Laura) Bye. Erin passes Laura, their eyes locking. Mark closes the do behind her and turns to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’ve just got so much I want to say. I forgot to give you this. She hands him the African violet. He puts it down.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What did you say to Drew?  oir

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I left a note. All that matters is that you want me and I want you. I don’t care -- Laura leans in to kiss but he pulls away--

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: -- see I do. I care. You of all people know that. This, right here, this matters. To me. To us.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I wrote a note. He deserved to know.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What? Exactly. Did he deserve?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I told him we were in love. Mark looks as if he’s been shot.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: You said what? Oh fuck me. We’re screwed. You’ve screwed me. Laura shrinks away from Mark, unsure how things ended up this. Mark looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not even supposed to still be here. I’ve got to be in Orlando. Flight leaves first thing. When I get back, we’ll fix this. I have no idea how but -- fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Orlando?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Work. It’s a boring trip. Laura grabs Mark desperately. She never wants to let him

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You have to stay. We have to talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I can’t. PR junket stuff, Paxton’s breathing down my neck -- no choice.  920 Laura’s heart sinks. She’s heard that line before and it’ enough to make her panic inside. She buries it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why? Why mess everything up when it was going so good? Laura can’t respond. She’s overcome. Searches for words -

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I wanted it to be real. Mark shakes his head and goes out the door leaving her al Laura stares ahead. No tears. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sits alone in the quiet simulator, the only crisis inside her head. There is a KNOCK. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Thought I'd find you out here. She looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just got the word. It’s official: you are selected for crew duty. You're going back Commander Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Atlantis?

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: You betcha. Laura stares straight ahead. No reaction. Flat. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not quite what I was expecting -- Laura looks at him as though from deep in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Say thank you. I know how bad you wanted this.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON
dialogues.text: Everything OK, Laura? Laura deploys a broad 100 watt grin.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Everything A-OK, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura walks down the hall. She sees DREW ahead, coming towards her.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. I got Atlantis. They chose me. She tries to go around him. Drew grabs her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Who is he? Laura tugs her arm away.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You wanna -- (looks around) -- keep your voice down.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: My voice? I lied to your kids last night, told them you were working a double shift.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was. I did. That’s -- I don’t know what you think -- He produces the crumpled paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Dear Drew. There’s no easy way to say this. I’ve fallen in love.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. That’s --

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Who is he? (beat) Laura, you need to come home. We have to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No, I -- they chose me. I told you. Atlantis. I’m going back up. So I've gotta --

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: It’s eighteen fucking months from now. You need to come home with me. Right now. Beat. Everything is spinning for her. There’s too much pressure.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: UTS to urine transfer hose. Closed.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Connect urine tranfer filter to faeces PD. Check. Clip receptical ASSY to transfer hose. Check. He stares at her. She is clearly losing her mind.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: What? Laura walks away from him, running her checklist, trying stay ahead of the feelings.

dialogues.speaker: DREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Laura!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: URA valve. Vent. Open. Management drain valve. Dump. Flush PKG, screen and honeycomb. Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura stands motionless under the shower head in the John gym. Hot water streams over her. She stares at her hand. Puts it in her mouth. And bites.  oor Her teeth sink into her own flesh. Deep. Blood streams ac the back of her hand. Laura stares straight ahead. She doesn’t wince. Doesn’t cry out. Just bites down as hard a she possibly can. Harder. She opens her jaws and her mout and teeth are covered with blood. She looks down at her hand. A deep semicircle bite mark p blood between her fingers onto the tiles. She wipes it across the shower wall. Staring into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura dials her phone.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE
dialogues.text: Hey you’ve reached Mark Goodman's cell. I can’t take your call right - Dials again.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey you’ve reached -- She dials again.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey you’ve reached Mark Goodman’s -- Again.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey you’ve reached -- Again.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey you’ve reached Mark Goodman’s --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura finds a tool box. She grabs a thin triangular file. takes out her office key. Begins to file the edges. Cutti row of jagged saw teeth the length of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late. Everyone gone. Almost everyone. Laura makes her way toward Mark’s darkened office. She tries the handle: lock Laura reaches into her bag, pulling out a drill hammer an her newly made bump key. She hits it a few times without success -- wincing at the noise -- then.

dialogues.speaker: -- CLICK--
dialogues.text: -- the tumblers bump. The key turns. And the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER - CONTINUOUS Laura slips in, shutting the door behind her. Mark's office is the same as it ever was-- more man-cave workspace. Two framed pictures-- Mark with his family and Mark with the Endeavor crew-- Laura picks up the picture the crew. She runs her finger across it. She goes through Mark's drawers but doesn't find much mor than a few Playboys and a giant tub of cheese puffs. Laura wakes up Mark's computer. Laura eats a few cheese p as she leans in, pecking at a few keys. She yanks opens t desk drawer. Mark's passwords are written on a Post-It ta to the side of the drawer. She logs in. Something catches eye: an email, sent from Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, space girl -- Laura stops. She checks the address-- ErinHawley@nasa.gov

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You were unbelievable last night. Searches the inbox for messages with Erin’s name. Hundred She sees the African violet in Mark’s trash can.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey. I miss you! I miss your body. So hot you’re emailing from space.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ERIN’S CAR. HOUSTON, TX - DAY We FLASH to images of Erin and Mark undressing each other The two of them having sex in the back of Erin's car.  or

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s mind blowing out here. I want you to experience this. I want us to share this magic. I only wish you were right here with me.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. BACKYARD. MARK GOODWIN’S HOUSE. HOUSTON, TX - DAY We flash to Mark’s Barbecue. Mark is sticking his hand un Erin’s shirt. She leans into him. In the distance, we see ex wife and kids preparing the grill.

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can’t wait for our weekend away. You’re gonna love Orlando. There’s this place I know. Can’t get a reservation. I know a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erin and Mark lay in the bed of Mark’s truck with blanket and pillows. They look up at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ll be on flight UA1946. There’s a two hour layover in Atlanta -- gross -- Gets in at six in the morning. I cannot wait to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARK’S OFFICE. JOHNSON SPACE CENTER -— CONTINUOUS Laura scribbles down UA1946. And 4.30am. She clicks email after email, until finally:

dialogues.speaker: MARK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Erin I never felt this way my whole life. Since being up here I feel like I have a whole planet of love I want to give you. I want to make you feel as wild and free as you make me feel every second we’re together. Love your Spaceboy. Laura looks up from the screen. No reaction. No histrioni Nothing. Flat. Emotionless. Numb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM. NANA’S APARTMENT — EVENING Dozens of pieces of paper are arranged around the room. O the floor. On furniture. Emails. Printed out. Wrinkled fr so much handling. The broken African violet from Mark's trash, it’s there too, like the sun in her solar system. LAURA PACES. A combination of very animated and oddly cal Moving fast. But her expression remains utterly flat. She stops her pacing at the kitchen counter and unscrews vodka bottle. Pours one. Drinks it. Pours another.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: DC power -- DC power from fuel cell 1 through the ESS bus source FC 1 switch on panel Rl when the switch is positioned to on and from main DC buses B and C through RPCs when the ESS bus source MN B/C switch on panel Rl is positioned to on. She knocks the second back and winces.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Positioned to ON. Positioned to on.

dialogues.speaker: THE DESK
dialogues.text: We see an ENVELOPE of CASH. Next to it is a CAN OF MACE. something else -- the .38 SPECIAL, fully loaded.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: checks her heartrate with two fingers and the second swee her watch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Positioned to on. She picks up the bottle of pills and shakes it rhythmical There should be enough to get her there. Laura goes over to her wall, where she’s pinned ROAD MAPS THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES.

dialogues.speaker: THE WALL
dialogues.text: There are ROUTES drawn on the MAP. First, a flight path i red Houston to Orlando, with a layover in Atlanta. “Travel time: 756 minutes. ETA: 08:32"  The other routes are less certain. DRIVING ROUTES, black marker. Most of them are abandoned halfway, travel times crossed out here and there.

dialogues.speaker: 99F
dialogues.text: drawn in ETAs and But now, finally, she might have it. Laura plots small ro across six states. She does a calculation before writing: “ETA: 05:30. Liftoff in T-6 mins."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight plan filed.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Positioned to ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura pushes a SHOPPING CART down the fluorescent grabbing items: -- a hunting KNIFE -- -- an oversized HAMMER -- -- yellow dishwashing GLOVES -- -- a bumper pack of diet sodas -- -- 2 bags of Twinkies -- -- a length of rubber surgical tubing -- -- a PACKAGE of DEPENDS ADULT DIAPERS

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: aisles, -- and, finally, from a polystyrene head in the hair prod aisle -- -- a BLACK WIG.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHECKOUT COUNTER
dialogues.text: A bored clerk rings her up.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Chewing her lips, antsy. She takes out her pill bottle, p two pills.  100.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Paper or plastic?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: The bag. You want paper or plastic?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Plastic. No, paper. No -- wait -- what’s the tensile strength of both bags, approximately? The clerk stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)

And he knows it

dialogues.text: Fine. She doesn’t look it.

dialogues.text: Sir -- you said some real nice things about me over the years and-

dialogues.text: Laura. I-

dialogues.speaker: PAXTON

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA

dialogues.speaker: LAURA

She’s deep in a trance until, fina -- a distant police siren breaks the silence. -- Laura stands up shakily -- looks around herself -- -- she hastily grabs something up off the ground -- -- and runs. Takes the stairs two at_a time. Wild-eyed. Moving as fast she can. Pulls at the rubber gloves, trying to get them o Tosses one in a trash can, drops the other and keeps runn But, Laura isn’t going down the stairs. She’s going up. S not trying to escape, she’s trying to get higher up. Up t

dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: / MISSION CONTROL, (0.S.)

dialogues.text: The ground far below her. She’s staring into the middle distance.  116.

dialogues.text: -- to fly into the great unknown --

dialogues.text: -- to see what it’s like. A RAPID MONTAGE OF FLOWERS OPENING PETALS. LAURA’S CHILDR
